interventions.Title: Cognitive Restructuring
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Cognitive restructuring can combat irrational beliefs that affect sexual self-esteem or performance anxiety.  
   **What to Do:** Identify negative thoughts about sex (e.g., "I am not good enough") and challenge them with evidence-based, more balanced thoughts.  
   **Example:** Replace "I will always disappoint my partner" with "Every couple has different preferences, and I can ask my partner what they enjoy."
interventions.extracted_value:
Identify the Trigger
Describe the situation that led to your negative emotions or thoughts.
What happened?


Where were you?


Who was involved?


How did you feel in the moment?


Record Your Automatic Thoughts
Write down the immediate thoughts that came to mind when the situation occurred. These are often negative, irrational, or distorted.
What were you thinking?


What meaning did you attach to the situation?


Challenge Your Thoughts
Examine the evidence for and against your negative thoughts, consider alternative perspectives, and develop more balanced or rational interpretations.
Is there any evidence to support your negative thought?


Is there any evidence to contradict your negative thought?


What are some alternative perspectives on this situation?


Can you reframe your negative thought into a more balanced or rational interpretation?

interventions.Title: Mindfulness Practices
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Mindfulness can reduce anxiety and increase present-moment awareness, enhancing sexual experiences.  
   **What to Do:** Practice focused breathing and pay attention to sensations without judgment during intimate moments.  
   **Example:** Before intimacy, take a few minutes to breathe deeply and focus on the current moment rather than worries about performance.
interventions.extracted_value:
What triggered my anxiety in this situation?


How did I breathe before and during the intimate moment?


What sensations did I notice during the intimate moment?


Were there any thoughts that distracted me from the present moment? If so, what were they?


How did focusing on my breath help me stay present?

interventions.Title: Behavioral Experiments
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Testing beliefs through action can provide new insights and reduce anxiety by disproving erroneous assumptions.  
   **What to Do:** Set up small, low-pressure experiments to challenge beliefs.  
   **Example:** If you believe trying something new will be embarrassing, plan a light-hearted date night where you and your partner try a new activity.
interventions.extracted_value:
What is the irrational thought or belief you want to challenge?


Describe the situation or event that triggers this irrational thought.
Plan a small, low-pressure experiment to test this belief. What specific action will you take?


How did you feel before and during the experiment?


What happened during the experiment? Did your actions align with your original belief?


How did your original thought change after the experiment?


What insights did you gain from this experiment? How might this change your behavior in similar situations?

interventions.Title: Graded Exposure
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Gradual exposure to feared situations can reduce anxiety and improve comfort levels.  
   **What to Do:** Start with less intimidating sexual activities, gradually moving towards more anxiety-provoking ones.  
   **Example:** Begin with non-sexual physical intimacy, like cuddling, and move progressively towards more intimate activities.
interventions.extracted_value:
What was the activity you engaged in today?


How did you feel before, during, and after the activity?


Did your SUDS rating change? If so, by how much?


What strategies did you use to manage your anxiety during the activity?


How comfortable did you feel after the activity? Rate from 0-10.


Are there any steps you need to take to progress to the next activity on your fear ladder?

interventions.Title: Thought Records
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Keeping track of thoughts can help identify and change patterns that negatively affect sexual desire or performance.  
   **What to Do:** Use a journal to note down situations, thoughts, emotions, and alternative thoughts.  
   **Example:** Write down when and why you felt anxious about sex, then consider alternative, supportive thoughts you could adopt next time.

interventions.Title: Communication Skills Training
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Enhancing communication can improve emotional intimacy and reduce misunderstandings around sex.  
   **What to Do:** Practice expressing needs and listening actively to your partner.  
   **Example:** Have an open conversation with your partner about what you both enjoy and any changes you want to explore sexually.
interventions.extracted_value:
Situation
What was the situation that led to this need for improved communication?
Who was involved in the situation?
Thoughts and Feelings
How did I explain the situation to myself?
What were my thoughts and feelings during the situation?
Were there any negative thoughts or feelings that arose?
Actions and Behaviors
What actions did I take during the situation?
How did I behave in response to the situation?
Outcome and Reflection
What was the outcome of the situation?
Did the outcome meet my expectations?
What did I learn from the experience?
Action Plan
What specific actions can I take to improve communication in similar situations in the future?
How can I practice expressing my needs more effectively?
How can I improve my active listening skills?

interventions.Title: Relaxation Techniques
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Relaxation can reduce tension and stress that interfere with sexual enjoyment.  
   **What to Do:** Practice deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery exercises.  
   **Example:** Before engaging in sexual activity, spend a few minutes doing deep breathing exercises to relax your mind and body.
interventions.Journal Template:
Section 1 Reflection on Current State
Question 1 How do you currently feel when you think about engaging in sexual activity? (e.g. anxious stressed relaxed)
XP 3
Question 2 What specific thoughts or emotions are contributing to your current state? (e.g. fear of performance past experiences)
XP 4
Question 3 How do these thoughts and emotions affect your behavior during sexual activity? (e.g. avoiding intimacy rushing through activities)
XP 5

interventions.Title: Positive Reframing
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Viewing situations through a positive lens can enhance self-esteem and relationship satisfaction.  
   **What to Do:** Identify negative spins and actively reframe them positively.  
   **Example:** Instead of thinking "We have less sex than before," reframe it as "We have more quality time together in different ways."

interventions.Title: Goal Setting
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Setting realistic goals can provide motivation and track progress in improving sexual relationships.  
   **What to Do:** Establish specific, achievable goals about sexual experiences or relationship improvements.  
   **Example:** Set a goal to have a date night once a week to foster connection and intimacy.
interventions.extracted_value:
What is my ultimate goal for improving my sexual relationship?


What specific, achievable goals can I set to improve my sexual relationship?


What actions can I take each day/week to move closer to my goal?


How will I track my progress towards my goal?


What potential barriers might I face in achieving my goal, and how can I overcome them?

interventions.Title: Self-Compassion Techniques
interventions.Description:
'**Why It Helps:** Cultivating self-compassion can reduce shame and increase acceptance, promoting a healthier sex life.  
    **What to Do:** Practice treating yourself with kindness when confronting sexual or relational setbacks.  
    **Example:** If you encounter an unsatisfactory sexual experience, remind yourself that it's okay and normal, and focus on what can be learned instead of self-criticism.

Implementing these CBT strategies can help individuals and couples work through obstacles in their sex lives, fostering greater satisfaction and intimacy. Each person may find some techniques more useful than others, and it's important to tailor them to personal needs and circumstances.
interventions.extracted_value:
What situation or event triggered my negative thoughts or feelings?


How did I initially react to the situation or event?


What self-critical thoughts came to mind?


What are the costs (negative outcomes) and benefits (positive outcomes) of thinking this way?


What compassionate thoughts could help alleviate my suffering and promote well-being in this situation?


How would my feelings change if I were to adopt a more compassionate perspective?


What is a more compassionate and helpful conclusion to replace the self-criticism?


How much do I believe the self-critical thoughts now (0-100%)?


How intense is my initial main emotion now (0-100%)?


What can I do to cope and look after myself in this situation?
